metadata.name: Make-believe #4
metadata.description:
#genuary32nd ‚Äì Let's meet on this make-believe date, in this make-believe place.
I‚Äôm having d√©j√† vu, or is it a memory?

This artwork is originally created for the genuary2023 prompt "Art Deco", using the same core algorithm as Memory Module. Made with fractal math and p5js.

Keyboard controls:
[s] Save the current view in live mode.
[1] to [8] Change resolution, 1.5K to 12K.
[g] Toggle texture.

URL params:
&aspect=[aspect ratio, eg 2]
&res=[resolution multiplier, 0.5-8]

Created by Elsif, 2023.02

metadata.name: Action; System #8
metadata.description:
Action; system is an experimental study inspired by the work of Fran√ßois Morellet. Morellet was one of the founders of the Groupe de Recherche d'Art Visuel (GRAV), founded in the 60s. His work was often informed by systems, a set of rules that determine the artwork, reducing the artist's subjectivity to a minimum.

This work explores what happens when we let go of the strict rule set. Do we ever fully let go?

-----------------
This work was released for the 2023 fundraising exhibition Cure3, and all of the proceeds and 1% of royalties will go to Parkinson's research funds. You can find more information at https://cure3.co.uk/.

-----------------
Controls
- R: new randomized output (the chances of recovering one of these outputs are very slim, that's what the next control is for)
- E: high-res output
- Double click: fullscreen

While you see the eye of Horus, your artwork is loading.

------------------
Made with p5.js & glsl
License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

metadata.name: Kralen #133
metadata.description:
The outputs created by this algorithm reminded me of the colourful bead mazes that children play with. So, I named the algorithm 'Kralen', which means 'beads' in Dutch.

The algorithm 'Kralen' creates random bezier curves using the edges of a rectangular boundary, and places beads atop these curves to create a 'bead maze' effect. The algorithm offers different curve creation modes, with the most common mode being 'Mix'. In this mode, two random edges of the boundary are chosen to form bezier curves. Other modes create curves that are horizontally or vertically oriented, or formed using only the corners of the boundary

---

The work is created with p5.js with the help of bezier.js for working with bezier curves.

metadata.name: Creatures #317
metadata.description:
A fish? A tiger? A phoenix? Some kind of monster?
Well‚Ä¶ I don't have the answer.
Find your Creature and decide what it is.

metadata.name: Angular Variations (Holding Space) #153
metadata.description:
Angular Variations. Holding space for transitions. Once minted the lines maintain their design while the spaces between adjust to accommodate changes in canvas size.

There are no rarity attributes assigned to this artwork, its value is intended to be determined by viewer aesthetic alone.

This artwork was created using p5js.

linktr.ee/lisaorthstudio
twitter: @lisaorthstudio

metadata.name: BETWEEN #33
metadata.description:
Between thought and embodiment.
A color that is not perceived by the human eye - is a radio wave. 
A structure that we cannot yet see, but it already exists - is a building project. 
Information that continues, despite the fact that there is a pause in the ether - is intuition. 
The BETWEEN project is about subtle worlds that are invisible, but always nearby.

This collection has been created with P5.js.
February 2023.
Press 'S' to save a 3375x4725 PNG file.

metadata.name: Fischinger #189
metadata.description:
Interactive Generative music piece inspired by the abstract animations of Oskar Fischinger. 
Click for new patterns.

Variations:
8 bgColors
7 shapeColors
5 rotations
5 playbackSpeeds
5 widths
2 bgPatterns

@ramioso 2021-11-20

objkt.name: THE WORD AFTER US: An AI poetry unreading #164

metadata.name: THE WORD AFTER US: An AI poetry unreading #164
metadata.description:
‚ÄúWhere in the world will words go, 
after us? How will they be arranged, 
and what will they sound like
when they arrive at their destination?
What will they be doing?
What will the world be doing?
Will the words be quiet or loud?
Will they be full of themselves,
or full of longing,
or full of longing‚Äôs opposite?‚Äù
 
An ars poetica on the future of literature and humanity. 
 
This project is a one-time generative poetry performance of a transhuman text by Sasha Stiles and her AI alter ego, Technelegy ‚Äì read and unread by an algorithm authored by Nathaniel Stern. Every hash transforms one of 353 lines of AI-written poetry from legible letters into wordless language, generating a unique textblock from millions of possible combinations; each algorithmic translation unwrites itself, forever. Press "s" to overlay and toggle the original line of verse, and watch its shapes and meanings degenerate ‚Äì or evolve ‚Äì into an infinite visual poem.
 
All minters will receive an airdropped broadside (mp4) of the entire original poem after the performance is complete. A 1/1 media-rich audiovisual version of THE WORD AFTER US will also be made available.

 
Poetic traits:
- 353 possible lines of generative poetry produced by a GPT-3 language model fine-tuned on Stiles‚Äô and Stern‚Äôs writing and research.
- 28 possible color palette combinations selected from Stern‚Äôs performative scanner art, with rare palettes including RGB, Hacker, Charcoal, and Chalkboard (black background).
- 6 possible fonts, including the premiere of Stern and Stiles‚Äô custom AI font, NNFT (Neural Network Font Type), developed for their ongoing collaboration, ‚ÄúMother Computer.‚Äù
- millions of layout and layering possibilities, including a rare ‚Äúspiral‚Äù effect.
- billions of animation attribute combinations, which carry on forever.

issuer.name: THE WORD AFTER US: An AI poetry unreading

metadata.name: (kinder)Garden, Monuments #250
metadata.description:
When Yazid and Zancan started their fxcollab journey, they knew very little about each other. They learnt about their rich cultural differences, their complementary graphic styles, and a 7-hour timezone difference. What they did have in common was each had two kids about the same age (one a pair of girls, the other boys).

Every kid was born a builder; every kid likes to sit in nature. It‚Äôs their way of discovering the world and dreaming of their future accomplishments. While they marvel at the heights of the cities and monuments they construct out of stacks of cubes, parents marvel at their ability to elaborate an unlimited range of worlds out of a limited range of materials. 

This project celebrates the humble and versatile cube. A deceptively simple yet powerful object of play and learning, regardless of age, whether you‚Äôre stacking them up in a sandbox, or learning 3D graphics for the first time. 

This project is dedicated to kids, those who were once children, to the dreamers and builders who still enjoy playing with cubes.

Coded in Vanilla JS, the project combines Yazid's iconic ‚ÄúHashed/Hatched‚Äù aesthetic incorporated into childhood wooden toy block structures, and Zancan's signature lush foliage and framework, which enables all iterations to be plottable.
 
Controls (in live view):
- Press [s] to get a SVG file suited for plotters
- Click on the image to download a 4K resolution PNG

metadata.name: Ethereal Microcosm #243
metadata.description:
An exploration of algorithmic organisms in a contained environment.

This piece is about the simulation of microscopic patterns using a high number of even tinier agents all following the same rules. Different species evolve and interact together, resulting in stabilizing patterns out of their parametric configurations. A form of artificial life.

This work is based on the paper "Characteristics of pattern formation and evolution in approximations of physarum transport networks", written by Jeff Jones and popularized in the artistic field by Sage Jenson. Some features were added to increase the visual and behavioral complexity of the system. Agents are divided into different species, with their own set of rules and interacting with their own substrate. Substrates also interact with each other and agents will mutate in contact of some of them.

NFT License
Runs properly on Chrome 97.0.4692.99
GPU intensive

Press P to pause (double tab touch devices)
Press

metadata.name: anaverse - Forbidden cities #61
metadata.description: A symbol of power and isolation.

metadata.name: Firmament #30
metadata.description:
Everyone remembers what they were doing when they first heard about it. I was trying to scrape peanut butter from the bottom of the jar with a knife. School bell rings at 4, I‚Äôm usually home by 4:12, it must have been 4:17 when I heard the news. The kitchen radio is always on. They interrupted the song and told everyone to stop what they were doing and to look up.

I looked up and saw the kitchen‚Äôs ceiling. Then I heard people shouting outside and I saw it through the window. The grid. White lines in the sky. Impossibly tall. Impossibly light. Impossibly bright. I ran upstairs to my room. I opened the door wide and climbed on the roof through the window. It made the sun look so small. I climbed down. I changed into my evening clothes and closed the door of the cupboard. It‚Äôs important to close the cupboard otherwise it blocks my room‚Äôs door and you can‚Äôt open it from the outside anymore.

It's been three weeks now. It‚Äôs been both a very short time and an eternity. Everyone keeps talking about it. Everyone has a theory about it. Self-proclaimed specialists yield more and more explanations. Everyone thinks they‚Äôre right, thinks that they know what the grid means, that they broke the cypher. I have a theory too. I didn‚Äôt tell anyone. I wrote it on a notebook that I keep in my desk, opposite the cupboard. I have to close the cupboard otherwise it blocks my room‚Äôs door and you can‚Äôt open it from the outside anymore.

My theory is that there is no meaning to the grid. It‚Äôs there as a distraction. While we‚Äôre thinking about it, we forget about the rest. They made the grid to fascinate us while they were spreading. They‚Äôre making progress and we still haven‚Äôt realized it. To be honest, I‚Äôm surprised their plan works so well. A grid, whatever kind of grid it is, is a very low effort form of visual representation. And still, people are fascinated. This is the only thing they talk about. It shines brighter than the moon during the night. It‚Äôs everywhere. The only place where I can‚Äôt see it‚Äôs light is in my cupboard. I should not forget to close the cupboard otherwise it blocks my room‚Äôs door and you can‚Äôt open it from the outside anymore.

I‚Äôm getting ready. I don‚Äôt have a hunting license yet. I was supposed to start taking shooting lessons in September, but that‚Äôs still months away. They won‚Äôt wait for me. I took a long knife in the kitchen. My parents haven‚Äôt noticed. They don‚Äôt notice much in normal times either. I hid it in my bed, between the frame and the mattress. I have a baseball bat in the cupboard. I always close it otherwise it blocks my room‚Äôs door and you can‚Äôt open it from the outside anymore. 

Many people don‚Äôt come to school anymore. I have two good friends in my class, they still come. In the larger group of people I talk to everyday, maybe half don‚Äôt come anymore. Parents don‚Äôt say anything. Maybe they don‚Äôt know? Teachers don‚Äôt really teach anyway. They‚Äôre fascinated like the rest of them. We don‚Äôt really understand why. It‚Äôs like they all suddenly found how the world works. Or maybe they all found that the world doesn‚Äôt work in a particular way, that none of it matters. Either way, every time I get back home and write in my notebook, I realize it‚Äôs getting worse. Yesterday I thought I should hide it somewhere else, like in the cupboard. I hope I closed the cupboard otherwise it blocks my room‚Äôs door and you can‚Äôt open it from the outside anymore.
 
I came home an hour ago. My parents are not there yet. I don‚Äôt know if they ever will come back. I just climbed into my room to check on my notebook. I had left it at the usual spot in my desk in the end. I opened it, took a pen, and then it slowly dawned on me. I took a pen and put in in my mouth as if I was pondering on what to write. The knife is too far, I‚Äôll never get to it. The chair is sturdy but it‚Äôs too heavy. The door of my cupboard is always closed otherwise it blocks my room‚Äôs door and you can‚Äôt open it from the outside anymore. Then why is it slightly open?

metadata.name: anaverse - Arcana sanctum #111
metadata.description: Sketches made by an anthropologist based on ancient texts describing the purgatory where lost souls wander.

metadata.name: Cit√©s nuageuses #201
metadata.description:
Un de mes fr√®res s‚Äôest envol√© hier. Ou avant-hier, je ne sais plus. Il a vendu du lest pour sortir une fille. Une bourrasque soudaine les a emport√©s, lui et ses deux tickets de cin√©ma.

Cela fait bien trois semaines que nous n‚Äôavons pas eu de livraison. Pas de courrier non plus, par la m√™me occasion. J‚Äôen re√ßois rarement. Je n‚Äôai jamais re√ßu qu‚Äôune lettre, en r√©alit√©. C‚Äô√©tait une longue lettre √©pistolaire de mon ami Dino. Il est cowboy, dans une cit√© voisine. 

Mon fr√®re connaissait cette fille depuis bien cinq ou six ans. Il √©taient au coll√®ge ensemble. Il y avait encore des livraisons toutes les semaines, √† cette √©poque. Parfois deux fois par semaine. On pouvait vendre des enclumes et acheter du petit lest. Poids pour poids, on y perdait. Mais avec √ßa on arrivait quand m√™me √† vivre.

C‚Äô√©tait le temps o√π les rochers n‚Äô√©taient pas attach√©s. Ils d√©rivaient rarement, le vent n‚Äô√©tait pas si fort. Et ils √©taient plus denses aussi. Aujourd‚Äôhui, un rocher qui n‚Äôest pas en laisse ne sera plus l√† demain.

√Ä l‚Äô√©poque, j‚Äô√©tais moi-m√™me cowboy. Je vivais avec Jacques, un bon copain. Il n‚Äôy avait rien de sexuel entre nous. On gardait les rochers. Un soir, on jouait √† l‚Äôespagnolette, il m‚Äôa relanc√© de trois alors que j‚Äô√©tais atout tr√®fle. Vous imaginez la suite. Je ne l‚Äôai plus jamais revu apr√®s √ßa.

Plus personne ne va au coll√®ge. Mon fr√®re √©tait d‚Äôune des derni√®res g√©n√©rations. Apr√®s √ßa les gens ne voyaient plus l‚Äôint√©r√™t. Tout devient de plus en plus l√©ger, et apprendre √† lire ou √©crire ne p√®se rien. Plus on mine, plus on vends des enclumes, plus on peut acheter du lest. Mais comme le lest est plus cher que les enclumes, √† force, la cit√© devient de moins en moins lourde.

Le vent est de plus en plus fort aussi. Je pense que c‚Äôest pour √ßa qu‚Äôil y a moins de livraisons. Il y a de moins en moins de cit√©s qui arrivent √† rester suspendues. Celle de Dino s‚Äôest envol√©e l‚Äôann√©e derni√®re, Dino avec. Avec moins de cit√©s √† visiter par voyage, les livraisons sont moins rentables.

Avant d‚Äô√™tre cowboy je construisais des ponts. C‚Äôest comme √ßa que j‚Äôai appris √† lier les rochers. Plus personne ne le fait aujourd‚Äôhui. Il faut commencer par ancrer le rocher domestique. Et apr√®s, il faut attendre. C‚Äôest la partie la plus difficile. Personne n‚Äôa appris √† suffisamment attendre. Parce que plus le temps passe, plus on devient l√©gers. Mais c‚Äôest le plus important. Il faut attendre le que rocher sauvage devienne suffisamment l√©ger. Sinon, il emportera le rocher domestique avec lui et on aura tout perdu.

Je me demande pourquoi il a achet√© ces deux tickets de cin√©ma. C‚Äôest toujours le m√™me film qui passe. Je ne l‚Äôai jamais vu. √áa parle de dialectique et de ma√ßonnerie, il para√Æt. Le cin√©ma c‚Äôest un domaine que je trouve trop contraignant. Encore une id√©e de bureaucrate. Places assign√©es. Horaires fixes. Un processus administratif au profit de la structure sociale. Classique. Les bureaucrates commencent toujours par nous exploiter et ils finissent par nous ali√©ner. ‚ÄúServir le peuple‚Äù, ils appellent √ßa. 

Cela fait des ann√©es que le pont est de moins en moins solide. De toutes les fa√ßons, on n‚Äôa rien pour le r√©parer. Nos rochers sont domestiqu√©s depuis le temps, mais ils s‚Äôentrainent les uns les autres au lieu de se stabiliser. La suspension des cit√©s, √ßa a l‚Äôair simple mais √ßa ne l‚Äôest pas vraiment. Quand elles ont √©t√© construites, avec les machines-outils des livreurs, elles √©taient bien suspendues. Mais peu √† peu, elles se sont d√©grad√©es. La seule richesse des cit√©s, c‚Äôest leur gravit√©. Pourquoi r√©parer ce qui est destin√© √† s‚Äôenvoler ?

Je comprends pourquoi mon fr√®re a vendu du lest. Apr√®s tout, le lest est l√† pour √™tre vendu tant qu‚Äôil vaut encore quelque chose. Jeudi dernier, le pont est tomb√©. Notre deuxi√®me rocher majeur est toujours reli√© par la chaine des rochers mineurs, mais elle ne va pas tenir longtemps. La cit√© va s‚Äôenvoler bient√¥t. Peut-√™tre demain ou apr√®s-demain. Je vous laisse, je dois aller miner.

attributes.name: Nombre de personnes dans la cit√©. ?
Nombre de laisses viables ?
attributes.value: C'est une vraie question. Je me souviens de ces longues soir√©es d'√©t√©, √† l'ombre des peupliers en fleurs. √Ä l'√©poque j'avais un adopt√© un chacal hollandais. Il √©tait sp√©cialis√© dans les ench√®res. Nous partagions quelques croquettes en regardant le vent secouer les nuages. Mais vous connaissez d√©j√† cette histoire, je me r√©p√®te.

metadata.name: Attachment #175
metadata.description:
The simplest of attachments still have elements of chaos.

The most complex may also feel the most secure.

S : Save current resolution
1 -> 4 : Save Low -> High Resolution

metadata.name: WTBS: Olympics Poster Edition #375
metadata.description:
WTBS: Olympics Poster Edition is our official collaboration with Jeres, who was kind enough to work with us in support of the show. The project leans into classic Olympic poster design motifs, embellished by Jeres' signature approach to color and shape. Huge thanks to Jeres for donating their time and enthusiasm to this one, we hope you enjoy it!

As with all WTBS projects, your minting will directly support the podcast and keep us going (and more importantly, collecting!). Our goal is to keep the show free from ads and fully supported by the community, your donations and contributions continue to make that possible. Thank you in advance to everyone who chooses to mint!

Jeres: I love vintage posters. When going to second-hand shops, flea markets or wherever people are selling their used goods, I‚Äôm always on the lookout for what people used to hang on their walls. Bauhaus-inspired posters, socialist propaganda, Nagel prints, anything art deco, etc.. but whenever I come across something Olympics inspired I always feel like I hit pay dirt. There‚Äôs something about the clean, simple design being used to show people coming together along with the undertones of human excellence that just feels special. And circles. I love circles. I hope you enjoy this collection as much as I enjoyed putting it together with Trinity and Will.
